item.title: [Mspolicy] Trouble on the Right – Why Conservatives Need to be Wary
item.description:
I only recently learned what a “groyper” is - you may or may not be familiar with the term? From what I can tell, a groyper is a hardline white nationalist.  Often anti-Semitic, groypers are hostile to mainstream conservatives.  To the extent they have a coherent agenda, groypers seem more national socialism than free-market capitalism. Having been […]

The post Trouble on the Right – Why Conservatives Need to be Wary appeared first on Mississippi Center for Public Policy.

item.title: [Alabamapolicy] The War of Visions
item.description:
Across the country, Americans are no longer divided simply by policy or party but by rival moral imaginations—two incompatible visions of truth, freedom, and even human nature itself.

item.title: [Mspolicy] A Very Grateful Immigrant’s Thanksgiving
item.description:
Having just celebrated Thanksgiving across the United States, I’ve been reminded of what makes this holiday truly special.  If you’re an American who’s grown up with the holiday your whole life, it’s easy to take it for granted. Speaking as an immigrant, let me tell you: there’s something genuinely magical about a country setting aside a […]

item.title: [Jbartlett] New Hampshire ranked freest state in North America for 24th time
item.description:
New Hampshire ranks as the freest state in North America, as measured in this year’s Economic Freedom of North America report, released today by the Josiah Bartlett Center for Public Policy in conjunction with Canada’s Fraser Institute. For the 24th time, New Hampshire is the freest state among all U.S. states, having scored 8.34 out […]

item.title: [Will Law] WILL Moves to Intervene in Wisconsin Redistricting Cases on Behalf of Wisconsin Voters
item.description:
WILL filed motions to intervene in two lawsuits seeking to overturn Wisconsin’s Congressional Maps. Seeking again to defend those maps on behalf of a group of Wisconsin voters, WILL argues that these new lawsuits are time-barred, the three-judge panel lacks authority to overrule the Wisconsin Supreme Court, and any attempt to impose new maps in this manner would violate federal law and the U.S. Constitution.

The post WILL Moves to Intervene in Wisconsin Redistricting Cases on Behalf of Wisconsin Voters appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.title: [Platteinstitute] Nebraska Tax Reform: Why Full Expensing Is the Smart Move
item.description:
The federal One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) creates the opportunity for Nebraska to adopt the most “America First” tax reform: full expensing. In an era of reshoring and friend-shoring critical supply chains, full expensing is the tax reform that properly defines “income” and incentivizes production in the U.S.A.   Full expensing is the policy of allowing...

item.description:
Nebraska’s zoning and permitting process for livestock operations is inconsistent, unpredictable, and varies widely from county to county. This report examines how Nebraska’s Conditional Use Permit (CUP) system works, the origins and goals of the Livestock Siting Assessment Matrix created under LB106, and why the Matrix remains underused nearly a decade later. Drawing on survey...

item.title: [Idahofreedom] The Battle for Health Freedom Isn’t Over: Let’s Fight for Children
item.description: Idaho’s “Medical Freedom Act (MFA)” protects adults from employers, businesses, government agencies, or other entities imposing medical interventions on them, including vaccines. Enacted this past July, the MFA protects adults from being coerced into using medical products, devices, substances, injections, or any technology, in any form. It’s simple — bodily autonomy is a fundamental, God-given […]

item.title: [Itrfoundation] If Massachusetts Can Rein In Property Taxes, Any State Can
item.description:
Despite ranking among the nation’s worst tax climates and having some of the highest income, sales, and property taxes, Massachusetts has successfully enforced a strong property tax cap through its Proposition 2½ for more than 40 years.
The cap limits annual levy growth to 2.5%, encourages disciplined budgeting, and includes a voter-approved override process, enabling communities to fund priorities without uncontrolled tax increases.
Massachusetts proves that even a high-spending state can maintain an effective property tax cap; Iowa can adopt similar limits without harming essential services or local government operations.

The post If Massachusetts Can Rein In Property Taxes, Any State Can appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Mountainstatespolicy] The Montana Constitution’s state university quagmire
item.description: One reason Montanans should opt for a new state constitutional convention in 2030 is that the 1972 constitution is plagued by poorly written language. The ensuing lawsuits give lawyers and judges power that belongs to the people and their elected representatives. Illustrative are the provisions governing the Montana University System (MUS). The document says, “The government and control of the Montana university system is vested in a board of regents . . . which shall have full power,...

item.description: In October, Meta announced a new “teen AI safety” approach for Instagram, Facebook, and its other platforms. Additionally, it’ll provide better insight into what their teens are doing with AI on Meta’s apps. item.title: [Itrfoundation] Rating Agencies Applaud Iowa’s Fiscal Strength, Caution on Spending
item.description:
S&P Global and Fitch Ratings have reaffirmed Iowa’s AAA credit rating, citing strong fiscal management, robust reserve levels, and prudent budgeting practices that continue to anchor the state’s financial position. Both rating agencies warned Iowa to maintain disciplined spending, noting risks tied to rising costs in education and Medicaid, economic headwinds in agriculture, and federal policy uncertainty that could pressure future budgets. As lawmakers prepare the FY 2027 budget, conservative budgeting remains key, with leaders encouraged to control spending growth to preserve Iowa’s strong reserves, credit rating, and long-term fiscal stability.

The post Rating Agencies Applaud Iowa’s Fiscal Strength, Caution on Spending appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Will Law] CDC Labels Minority Neighborhoods as “Vulnerable,” Encouraging the Spread of DEI Spending Nationwide
item.description:
In new findings provided to the Trump Administration’s Health and Human Services (HHS) agency, WILL has uncovered that the Center for Disease Control (CDC) uses a race-based criteria to declare whole communities and neighborhoods as “socially vulnerable” based on the number of minorities living there. Cities and states around the country rely on the CDC’s “social vulnerability index” (SVI) to allocate taxpayer funding for parks, drinking water, and disaster assistance.  

The post CDC Labels Minority Neighborhoods as “Vulnerable,” Encouraging the Spread of DEI Spending Nationwide appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.title: [Johnlocke] Federal Education Policy
item.description:

From our nation’s infancy, Congress generally adhered to the principle that the federal government had no authority to undertake functions and duties not enumerated in the Constitution. As such, the nation relied on families, communities, and state and local governments to direct the education of the...

The post Federal Education Policy appeared first on John Locke Foundation.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] Taxes, Turnout, and the Power of Participation
item.description:
In November 2025, Iowa voters weighed in on 58 local bond proposals, which directly affect property tax bills for up to 20 years, with turnout significantly higher than in other local races. Average turnout for bond elections was 37.1%, more than double the statewide average for city and school elections, suggesting voters engage more when long-term tax impacts are clear. Higher voter participation leads to more representative outcomes in bond elections, reinforcing the importance of transparency and engagement in decisions that commit communities to long-term spending.

The post Taxes, Turnout, and the Power of Participation appeared first on ITR Foundation.
